title: Online compiler: uVision 5 export for K64F is broken
Const correct valuePtr in GattCharacteristic constructors
body:
With respect to [the GattCharacteristic constructor](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/2259e0d539fdfc8bee985b2a47212170ff253d1b/features/FEATURE_BLE/ble/GattCharacteristic.h#L326) and its template specializations, shouldn't `uint8_t * valuePtr` and `T * valuePtr` be marked `const`?

If the underlying stack makes a copy of the incoming value, would it make sense for the compiler to guarantee that the input value is not modified? Or are people actually passing a value back via this pointer?

title: Inflated hex file size when compiling with mbed cli compared to online
body:
I'm trying transition from mbed-classic to mbed OS5 for a large project I have. My target is NRF51_DK_BOOT. I'm using GCC_ARM.
The mbed-os version I'm testing was this:
https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/#65956d108e822d50acb617d0f4b0cafdb2a91d5f
and also
https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/tree/feature-nrf5_dfu_s13x_v2

I am experiencing the following error:

AddressOverlapError: Data overlapped at address 0x3C000

I tried "--profile small" but I still get this error.

The NRF51_DK target compiles, but results in a very large hex (~689K).
Why is it so big? When I compile the same project with the online compiler I get a hex that is ~546KB for NRF51_DK and ~555KB for NRF51_DK_BOOT.

title: GR PEACH strange behavior when using InterruptIn
[Proposal] Simplify build profiles: debug and release only
body:
## Description
I think our build profile story is a bit complicated and not clear. What's default profile? It doesn't mean much, requires checking documentation and leads to assumptions and issues. I think default build should be make in `debug` mode and as most environments/projects we should have clear `release` mode. 

I've decided to remove default profile, make debug the default and rename small to release.

Let me know what do you think.

CC: @bridadan @theotherjimmy @0xc0170

title: uVisor: Standardize available legacy heap and stack
body:
With the RTOS, the STACK_SIZE specified here is unrelated to the stack
size available for the main thread (that runs pre_main). Save memory by
reducing the stack size to a more reasonable amount.

On uVisor, HEAP_SIZE is both a minimum available and maximum available
heap size. The heap can't grow beyond the end of the heap into the
neighboring stack. On all uVisor-supported platforms, guarantee at least
0x6000 bytes of heap space. This increases the portability of uVisor
applications as the memory available for legacy heap allocations is
guaranteed. This helps to avoid out of memory errors on platforms that
were previously guaranteeing less memory.

## Status
**READY**

 @0xc0170 @AlessandroA

body:
### Description
- Type: Question
- Priority: Minor

## Question
I would like to debug mbed CLI generated ELF file with toolchain set to *ARM* in Keil uVision debugger. This is useful as some issue cannot re-produce thru exported uVision project. For example, I would like to debug *mbed-os-example-blinky*. With build command line below, I get *mbed-os-example-blinky.elf*.
```
mbed compile -t ARM -m NUMAKER_PFM_NUC472 --profile mbed-os/tools/profiles/debug.json
```

Following the link below to generate a dummy Keil uVision project, e.g. *debug-mbed*. I can flash *mbed-os-example-blinky.elf*, enter debug session, and start source-level debugging in this dummy project.
http://www.keil.com/support/docs/2310.htm
In debug session, I can step-run, but fail to set BP in most source files e.g. main.cpp (with **Run to main()** unchecked) until I step into that source file. In my opinion, it would be reasonable for Keil to debug external ELF file generated by itself even thru mbed CLI as long as debug information is included.

5.17
**mbed CLI**
1.0.0
**mbed-os-example-blinky**
mbed-os-5.3.4
**mbed-os**

title: Issues with the fixed heap size in IAR
body:
I compiled a project for K64F with three compilers (GCC_ARM, ARMCC and IAR). The binaries compiled with GCC_ARM and ARMCC worked fine,  but the one compiled with IAR failed with an out of memory error. After further investigation, it appears that IAR linker command file declares a maximum size for the heap, which is enforced at runtime:

https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/targets/TARGET_Freescale/TARGET_MCUXpresso_MCUS/TARGET_MCU_K64F/device/TOOLCHAIN_IAR/MK64FN1M0xxx12.icf#L85
https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/targets/TARGET_Freescale/TARGET_MCUXpresso_MCUS/TARGET_MCU_K64F/device/TOOLCHAIN_IAR/MK64FN1M0xxx12.icf#L104

This isn't consistent with GCC_ARM and ARMCC, which check for a heap/stack colision first, and only then with a dynamically computed heap limit (https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/platform/retarget.cpp#L596).

So the question is, what can be done to make this consistent in all three toolchains? As a quick fix, it appears that it's possible to declare the heap without a maximum size in IAR:

```
define block HEAP      with alignment = 8     { };
```

The above change fixes my particular issue, but I'm not sure about its full implications.

@marcuschangarm

title: Honor OS_MAINSTKSIZE setting
body:
I'm using the NRF52832, and ran into a problem with mbedTLS using more than 2K of stack memory, which causes a stack overflow with the default main thread configuration. 

Changing `OS_MAINSTKSIZE` didn't fix the problem, and I needed to understand why.

The bug hunt is documented here:
https://vilimpoc.org/blog/2017/02/01/stack-heap-and-thread-crash-hunting-in-mbed-os/

## OS_MAINSTKSIZE isn't being honored

**RTX_CM_lib.h**

Here is the definition of the main thread's stack memory area:

```c
#if defined(TARGET_MCU_NRF51822) || defined(TARGET_MCU_NRF52832) || defined (TARGET_STM32F334R8) ||\
    defined(TARGET_STM32F070RB) || defined(TARGET_STM32F072RB) || \
    defined(TARGET_STM32F302R8) || defined(TARGET_STM32F303K8) || defined (TARGET_STM32F334C8) ||\
    defined(TARGET_STM32F103RB)
static uint32_t thread_stack_main[DEFAULT_STACK_SIZE / sizeof(uint32_t)];
#elif defined(TARGET_XDOT_L151CC)
static uint32_t thread_stack_main[DEFAULT_STACK_SIZE * 6 / sizeof(uint32_t)];
#else
static uint32_t thread_stack_main[DEFAULT_STACK_SIZE * 2 / sizeof(uint32_t)];
#endif
osThreadDef_t os_thread_def_main = {(os_pthread)pre_main, osPriorityNormal, 1U, sizeof(thread_stack_main), thread_stack_main};
```

Following `DEFAULT_STACK_SIZE` leads to **cmsis_os.h**:

```c
#if defined(TARGET_XDOT_L151CC)
#define DEFAULT_STACK_SIZE         (WORDS_STACK_SIZE/2)
#else
#define DEFAULT_STACK_SIZE         (WORDS_STACK_SIZE*4)
#endif
```

which leads to (also **cmsis_os.h**):

```c
// The stack space occupied is mainly dependent on the underling C standard library
#if defined(TOOLCHAIN_GCC) || defined(TOOLCHAIN_ARM_STD) || defined(TOOLCHAIN_IAR)
#    define WORDS_STACK_SIZE   512
#elif defined(TOOLCHAIN_ARM_MICRO)
#    define WORDS_STACK_SIZE   128
#endif
```

So setting `OS_MAINSTKSIZE = 512` in `mbed_rtx.h` (`targets/TARGET_NORDIC/mbed_rtx.h`) does nothing.

This change pulls `OS_MAINSTKSIZE` into `RTX_CM_lib.h` if it is defined.

**Note**

One negative aspect of this is that if the user has not defined `ISR_STACK_SIZE` somewhere, then changing `OS_MAINSTKSIZE` also changes that derived parameter (so doubling it doubles the ISR/OS scheduler stack size):

```c
/* Define stack sizes if they haven't been set already */
#if !defined(ISR_STACK_SIZE)
    #define ISR_STACK_SIZE ((uint32_t)OS_MAINSTKSIZE * 4)
#endif
```

title: NRF51822: HAL: Restore WEAK declaration for hal_(deep)sleep
Issue in exporting sample to GCC (ARM Embedded) toolchain on mbed online compiler
body:
### Description
- Type: Bug
- Priority: Major

-----------------------------------------------------------------
## Bug
As shown below, it seems that '-include mbed_config.h' is specified for g++ compiler
option only when exporting a program to GCC ARM Embedded on mbed online compiler.


```
CC_FLAGS = $(CPU) -c -g -fno-common -fmessage-length=0 -Wall -Wextra -Wno-unused-parameter -Wno-missing-field-initializers
CC_FLAGS += -fno-exceptions -fno-builtin -ffunction-sections -fdata-sections -fno-delete-null-pointer-checks -fomit-frame-pointer
CC_FLAGS += -MMD -MP


CPPC_FLAGS = -c -Wall -Wextra -Wno-unused-parameter -Wno-missing-field-initializers -fmessage-length=0 -fno-exceptions 
*snip* -DDEVICE_SPISLAVE=1 -DDEVICE_ANALOGIN=1 -DDEVICE_PWMOUT=1 -include mbed_config.h -MMD -MP
```

We think **-include mbed_config.h** should be needed not only for CPPC_FLAGS, but also for both CC_FLAGS and CPPC_FLAGS.
Otherwise, a compilation error should occur.

Please note that the issue might not occur if mbed export command is used for export.

Could you give us your opinion about the above?

title: Adding case insensitive 'error' detection
body:
## Description
GCC Assembler errors were being missed because it prints 'error' with a captial 'E'. This change allows the 'e' to be either lower case or upper case.


## Status
**READY**


## Migrations
If this PR changes any APIs or behaviors, give a short description of what *API users* should do when this PR is merged.

NO


## Related PRs
This may conflict with https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/pull/3653


## Todos
- [x] Tests


## Notes
Before, the tools would miss errors like the following when it was printed from the assembler:

```
/tmp/ccXLitIR.s: Assembler messages:
/tmp/ccXLitIR.s:677: Error: cannot honor width suffix -- `mov r1,#0'
/tmp/ccXLitIR.s:679: Error: cannot honor width suffix -- `mov r0,#0'
/tmp/ccXLitIR.s:727: Error: cannot honor width suffix -- `mov r1,#4'
/tmp/ccXLitIR.s:729: Error: cannot honor width suffix -- `neg r1,r1'
/tmp/ccXLitIR.s:731: Error: cannot honor width suffix -- `mov r5,#4'
/tmp/ccXLitIR.s:737: Error: cannot honor width suffix -- `mov r1,#3'
/tmp/ccXLitIR.s:739: Error: cannot honor width suffix -- `neg r1,r1'
/tmp/ccXLitIR.s:741: Error: cannot honor width suffix -- `mov r5,#3'
/tmp/ccXLitIR.s:743: Error: cannot honor width suffix -- `neg r5,r5'
/tmp/ccXLitIR.s:754: Error: cannot honor width suffix -- `orr r5,r2'
```

title: STM rtc_isenabled() returns false positive
body:
### Description
- Type: Bug
- Priority: Minor

The mbed RTC API used to allow calls to time() without a preceding set_time() call. The API would detect that the RTC was not yet initialized or running and initialize it before returning the time to ensure that the returned time was valid. This is no longer true for STM targets. If the platform has DEVICE_LOWPOWERTIMER defined, the RTC behaves as expected, but otherwise the RTC is not initialized unless set_time() is explicitly called because rtc_isenabled() unconditionally returns success in this case.

This should be fixed or the change in behavior explicitly documented. I'm unsure as to why the RTC_ISR is only checked if DEVICE_LOWPOWERTIMER is defined. @bcostm, is this not also sufficient to determine if the RTC is running when DEVICE_LOWPOWERTIMER is undefined? I tested this on XDOT_L151CC platform and it appears to work.

I understand that adding a set_time() call resolves this, but I'm concerned about subtle changes in behavior like this breaking applications that were unknowingly (or knowingly) relying on them.

I will submit a PR adding a RTC unit test for this case. I will also look into submitting a PR with a fix for this issue.

---------------------------------------------------------------
## Bug

**Target**
Tested on XDOT_L151CC. Affects any STM target which has DEVICE_RTC defined and DEVICE_LOWPOWERTIMER undefined.

**Toolchain:**
GCC_ARM|ARM|IAR

**mbed-cli version:** 
0.9.1

**meed-os sha:**
269f58d Merge pull request #3660 from ARMmbed/release-candidate

**DAPLink version:**
0241

**Expected behavior**
When calling time(NULL) without a previous set_time() call, the RTC API should properly detect that RTC is not running and initialize it.

**Actual behavior**
If DEVICE_LOWPOWERTIMER is undefined, rtc_isenabled() simply returns 1, causing time() calls without a preceding set_time() call to return a constant, invalid value.

**Steps to reproduce**
Building and running the following application on a MTS xDot or any other ST platform that defines DEVICE_RTC but not DEVICE_LOWPOWERTIMER should cause a constant invalid time to get printed out the debug port. Uncommenting the set_time() line resolves the issue.

```C++
#include "mbed.h"

Serial pc(USBTX, USBRX);

int main() {
    //set_time(1256729737);

    while (true) {
        printf("time %d\r\n", time(NULL));
        wait_ms(2000);
    }
}
```

title: Dev stm32 gpio pins rework
body:
## Description
This PR is an update of the pins, gpio and gpio irqs management. 

Until now all those 3 services were using the same STM32 high level service from HAL which was a bit cumbersome. After this change the design is simpler and each drivers gpio_api.c, gpio_irq_api.c and pinmap.c will manage the corresponding registers in an independant way. 

After this PR, we have following benefit:
- simpler design pattern as explained above
- common code for those drivers instead of 1 driver per STM family. Only the family specific part s managed in a separate pin_device.h file. Mostly F1 family has a specific implementation.
- increased performances  (addressing #3299)
- will BTW solve timeout issues when running PWM tests with ci-test-shield (as in here #3501)

title: Fixed a problem that the STOP2 was falling back to STOP1
body:
The LPR was not turned on when entering into STOP2. Now the deepsleep mode on the STM32L4 Nucleo board needs only 1.6uA instead of 10uA.

This is described in the STM RM0351 Reference manual, Section PWR registers BIT-14
Note: Stop 2 mode cannot be entered when LPR bit is set. Stop 1 is entered instead.

I am pretty happy that I figured this out.

Regards Helmut

title: mbed storage: FATFileSystem::format() has incorrect allocation unit arg to f_mkfs()
body:
There are 2 points to this issue:
- 	The FATFileSystem::format() calls f_mkfs with incorrect third argument if the sdcard has not been formatted with 512 byte cluster size. This is a coding bug and should be fixed.
-	How to expose f_mkfs() so this can be fixed in a general way.

## Bug Discussion

- From the chanFS documentation the value of allocation_unit=0 in f_mkfs(x, y, allocation_unit=0) means the default value of the allocation unit is assumed (http://elm-chan.org/fsw/ff/en/mkfs.html) i.e. 32768 bytes. This suggests the sdcards you're using have 32768 bytes as the allocation unit.
- FATFileSystem::format() calls f_mkfs() with (likely) incorrect value for the allocation unit. This needs to be fixed. 

## API Change discussion

Regarding the 2nd point:
>> The question is what kind of API you can expose to allow calling format.

I’m not sure what you’re thinking here. The API is already exposed in the FATFileSystem::format(). As I understand it, we just need to fix the 3rd arg.

Are you thinking that we should have: 

```
int FATFileSystem::format(int allocation_unit)
... 
    FRESULT res = f_mkfs(_fsid, 0, allocation_unit); // Logical drive number, Partitioning rule, Allocation unit size (bytes per cluster)
```
## Misc

**Actual behavior**
See email below.

**Steps to reproduce**
See email below.

-----------------------------------------------------------------

email from Daniel Benor describing this issue:

From: Daniel Benor 
Sent: 30 January 2017 17:59
To: Simon Hughes
Cc: Clive Bluston
Subject: file system corruption investigation

hi Simon
Hope you feel better.
I wanted to share with you some findings related to file system corruption:
During development Clive found that the file system got corrupted once or twice a day.
I could reproduce the corruption by pressing the reset button during our tests. after 5-15 times I got a corruption that could be fixed with chkdsk in the PC.
I tried calling   f_mkfs(_fsid, 1U, 0U); in a small test after the corruption and I saw that this fixed the sd card, and there was no need to extract it and run chkdsk.

I tried calling sd.format from our CPP file that calls mbedOS API, but I got stuck. I changed the parameters of  f_mkfs as shown below and this solved the problem.
I added a call to sd.format on starting our tests and now I can't reproduce the file system corruption.
Even after corruption if I run our tests, sd.format is fixing the corruption.

The question is what kind of API you can expose to allow calling format. This will be very required in CI testing system.
Any comments or questions will be appreciated
Danny

```
int FATFileSystem::format() {
    lock();
    FRESULT res = f_mkfs(_fsid, 1U, 0U); // Logical drive number, Partitioning rule, Allocation unit size (bytes per cluster)
//    FRESULT res = f_mkfs(_fsid, 0, 512); // Logical drive number, Partitioning rule, Allocation unit size (bytes per cluster)
    if (res) {
        debug_if(FFS_DBG, "f_mkfs() failed: %d\n", res);
        unlock();
        return -1;
    }
    unlock();
    return 0;
}
```

title: Renamed files in platform to match source names
body:
Small pr to rename the files in platform to match source names.

Here's the changed files
```
critical.h     -> mbed_critical.h
sleep.h        -> mbed_sleep.h
toolchain.h    -> mbed_toolchain.h
rtc_time.h     -> mbed_rtc_time.h
semihost_api.h -> mbed_semihost_api.h
```

``` bash
sed -i 's/#include "\(.*\)\<\(critical\|sleep\|toolchain\|rtc_time\|semihost_api\|wait_api\).h"/#include "\1mbed_\2.h"/' $(find -regex '.*\.\(h\|hpp\|c\|cpp\)')
```

title: mbed TLS examples fail intermitently when using the online IDE
body:
### Description
- Type: Bug
- Related issue: https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os-example-tls/issues/31
- Priority: Minor

This issue was originally reported in the mbed TLS examples repository: https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os-example-tls/issues/31.

The mbed TLS examples intermittently fail to compile when using the mbed online IDE. The failure causes vary between the examples and sometimes the same example exhibits different faults depending on the time of compilation. Errors are related to:

* The online IDE fails to load, hangs, seems to be stuck doing some operations.
* Compilation errors are reported for no good reason since the programs compile without problems using the offline tools e.g. mble-cli, Makefiles, IAR, uVision, etc...

---------------------------------------------------------------
## Bug

**Target**
Its irrelevant, the same issue happened when compiling for multiple targets. (e.g. K64F, NUMAKER_PFM_NUC472, etc)

**Toolchain:**
The compiler used by the mbed online IDE at https://developer.mbed.org/compiler/. I suspect its ARMC5.

**mbed-os sha:**
The default version when importing the following mbed TLS examples into the online IDE through the website:
* https://developer.mbed.org/teams/mbed-os-examples/code/mbed-os-example-tls-tls-client/
* https://developer.mbed.org/teams/mbed-os-examples/code/mbed-os-example-tls-benchmark/
* https://developer.mbed.org/teams/mbed-os-examples/code/mbed-os-example-tls-hashing/
* https://developer.mbed.org/teams/mbed-os-examples/code/mbed-os-example-tls-authcrypt/

**Expected behavior**
Compilation should succeed without errors.

**Actual behavior**
Compilation reports (different) errors intermittently.

**Steps to reproduce**
* Import an mbed TLS example into the IDE.
* Compile the program for one of the supported targets (say K64F).
* A compilation error is reported (note that it is an intermittent fault and we have no information regarding the probability of failure).

title: mbed TLS benchmark example fails compilation in online IDE for NUC472
body:
### Description
- Type: Bug
- Related issue: https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os-example-tls/issues/33
- Priority: Major

This is an issue that was originally reported in the mbed TLS examples repo at https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os-example-tls/issues/33. The problem is that compilation of the mbed TLS benchmark example fails for the platform NUMAKER_PFM_NUC472 when using the Online IDE. However, it does work correctly when compiling using the command line tools (mbed-cli) or the Makefiles generated by the exporter (mbed export).

I did some brief investigation and it seems that not all the macros in the `device_has` field of the target.json for the NUMAKER_PFM_NUC472 are present when compiling with the online IDE. Specifically, I found out that the macro `DEVICE_TRNG` is not present. This macro enables usage of entropy sources for mbed TLS in mbed OS, this might be part of the problem.

---------------------------------------------------------------
## Bug

**Target**
NUMAKER_PFM_NUC472

**Toolchain:**
I do not know what is used in the Online IDE at https://developer.mbed.org/compiler/. I suspect is ARMC5.

**mbed-os sha:**
#34c1facf42a174f47fdf9002cd8c6bf10ac41744. The default in the example's `mbed-os.lib` file.

**Expected behavior**
The example should compile without errors.

**Actual behavior**
When compiling with the online IDE, the following compilation errors are reported:
```
Error: Undefined symbol mbedtls_hardware_poll (referred from entropy.NUMAKER_PFM_NUC472.o)
```

**Steps to reproduce**
* Import the mbed TLS examples from the URL https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os-example-tls.git into the online IDE.
* Change the platform to NUMAKER_PFM_NUC472.
* Compile the benchmark application
* Observe the failure message at the end of the compilation process.

title: Why pinmap_pinout is setting pin into PullNone mode ?
body:
I am wondering why the below line of code was introduced:
https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/hal/mbed_pinmap_common.c#L27

This makes things more complex than should be, at least for STM targets, and maybe for others as well.

Here is what happens:
Drivers calls to pinmap_pinout
pinmap_pinout 
|_ pin_function
--------- |_ here the target specific code, selects an alternate function.
--------- in case of STM32 targets, it also selects appropriate mode (OpenDrain, PullDown ...)
--------- |_ pin_mode(pin, PullNone);
------------------ here the common code over-writes the default configuration set above
------------------ this means that the driver now specifically has to set mode again, calling to 
|_ pin_mode(pin, PullDown );

I would consider removing the line, 
https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/hal/mbed_pinmap_common.c#L27
assuming that targets have default mode settings that are possibly a better fit than PullNone.

Any feedback ?

title: ARM GCC toolchain not initializing RTOS
body:
Hi, I had some problems running mbed code compiled with ARM GCC toolchain. For details, see: [ARM GCC toolchain not initializing RTOS (was: simple RTOS example ends in HardFault_Handler)](https://developer.mbed.org/questions/76743/ARM-GCC-toolchain-not-initializing-RTOS-/).

### Description
- Type: Bug
- Priority: Blocker

---------------------------------------------------------------
## Bug

**Target**
LPC176X

**Toolchain:**
GCC_ARM

**mbed-os:**
mbed-os master (5.2.1)

**Expected behavior**
[RTOS Thread example](https://docs.mbed.com/docs/mbed-os-api-reference/en/latest/APIs/tasks/rtos/) is running and the LEDs are flashing.

**Actual behavior**
HardFault_Handler() is called when the (RTOS) Thread is created. The problem is that the necessary RTOS initialization routines were not called.

**Steps to reproduce**
Compile the code with a GCC_ARM compiler using the [current startup file](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/targets/TARGET_NXP/TARGET_LPC176X/device/TOOLCHAIN_GCC_ARM/startup_LPC17xx.S).

**Possible solution**
I created the following code (.c file instead of the .S file) which worked in that case and also for the [HTTP client program example](https://docs.mbed.com/docs/mbed-os-api-reference/en/latest/APIs/communication/ethernet/). I have not tested any possible case the mbed-os library is capable of. 

`/*----------------------------------------------------------------------------`
`    Description: LPC17xx startup file for ARM GCC compilers`
`    Copyright:   unknown, files did not contain any copyright info`
`    License:     unknown, files did not contain any license info`
`- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -`
`    Note: This file is a adption of the basic startup code from Sysprogs`
`          (ORIGINAL_CR_startup_lpc175x_6x.c), extended with functionality from`
`          mbed TOOLCHAIN_GCC_CR (startup_LPC17xx.cpp) to call the necessary`
`          routines to run CMSIS RTOS/RTX from mbed.`
`- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -`
`    THE SOFTWARE IS PROVIDED "AS IS", WITHOUT WARRANTY OF ANY KIND, EXPRESS OR`
`    IMPLIED, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO THE WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY,`
`    FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE AND NONINFRINGEMENT. IN NO EVENT SHALL`
`    THE AUTHORS OR COPYRIGHT HOLDERS BE LIABLE FOR ANY CLAIM, DAMAGES OR OTHER`
`    LIABILITY, WHETHER IN AN ACTION OF CONTRACT, TORT OR OTHERWISE, ARISING`
`    FROM, OUT OF OR IN CONNECTION WITH THE SOFTWARE OR THE USE OR OTHER`
`    DEALINGS IN THE SOFTWARE.`
`-----------------------------------------------------------------------------*/`
` `
`// common defintions`
`#define NULL ((void *)0)`
` `
`// Local functions`
`void Reset_Handler();`
`void Default_Handler();`
` `
`// External functions`
`extern void SystemInit(void);`
`extern void pre_main(void) __attribute__((weak));`

`extern void* __data_end__;`

` `

`{`

`    &I2C2_IRQHandler,          // 28: I2C2`
`    &SPI_IRQHandler,           // 29: SPI`
`    &SSP0_IRQHandler,          // 30: SSP0`
`    &SSP1_IRQHandler,          // 31: SSP1`
`    &PLL0_IRQHandler,          // 32: PLL0 Lock (Main PLL)`
`    &RTC_IRQHandler,           // 33: Real Time Clock`
`    &EINT0_IRQHandler,         // 34: External Interrupt 0`
`    &EINT1_IRQHandler,         // 35: External Interrupt 1`
`    &EINT2_IRQHandler,         // 36: External Interrupt 2`
`    &EINT3_IRQHandler,         // 37: External Interrupt 3`
`    &ADC_IRQHandler,           // 38: A/D Converter`
`    &BOD_IRQHandler,           // 39: Brown-Out Detect`
`    &USB_IRQHandler,           // 40: USB`
`    &CAN_IRQHandler,           // 41: CAN`
`    &DMA_IRQHandler,           // 42: General Purpose DMA`
`    &I2S_IRQHandler,           // 43: I2S`
`    &ENET_IRQHandler,          // 44: Ethernet`
`    &RIT_IRQHandler,           // 45: Repetitive Interrupt Timer`
`    &MCPWM_IRQHandler,         // 46: Motor Control PWM`
`    &QEI_IRQHandler,           // 47: Quadrature Encoder Interface`
`    &PLL1_IRQHandler,          // 48: PLL1 Lock (USB PLL)`
`    &USBActivity_IRQHandler,   // 49: USB Activity`
`    &CANActivity_IRQHandler,   // 50: CAN Activity`
`};`
` `
` `
`// Reset_Handler(): Entry point after reset`
`void __attribute__((naked, noreturn)) Reset_Handler()`
`{`
`    // Copy initialized RAM section from Flash`
`    void **pSource, **pDest;`
`    for (pSource = &__etext, pDest = &__data_start__; pDest != &__data_end__; pSource++, pDest++)`
`        *pDest = *pSource;`
`    `
`    // Initialize BSS section in RAM`
`    for (pDest = &__bss_start__; pDest != &__bss_end__; pDest++)`
`        *pDest = 0;`
` `
`    // Run system intialization`
`    SystemInit();`
`    `
`    if (pre_main)`
`    {`
`        // give control to the RTOS`
`        software_init_hook(); // this will also call __libc_init_array`
`    }`
`    else`
`    {`
`        // for BareMetal (non-RTOS) build`
`        __libc_init_array();`
`        (void)main();`
`    }`
`    `
`    // done - this should never be reached`
`    for (;;) ;`
`}`
` `
` `
`// The Default_Handler that gets executed if your code is missing an interrupt handler`
`void __attribute__((naked, noreturn)) Default_Handler()`
`{`
`    //If you get stuck here, your code is missing a handler for some interrupt.`
`    for (;;) ;`
`}`

title: Socket should provide information about what state change caused an event
body:
### Description
- Type: Enhancement

In the socket callback function:

```
    /** Register a callback on state change of the socket
     *
     *  The specified callback will be called on state changes such as when
     *  the socket can recv/send/accept successfully and on when an error
     *  occurs. The callback may also be called spuriously without reason.
     *
     *  The callback may be called in an interrupt context and should not
     *  perform expensive operations such as recv/send calls.
     *
     *  @param func     Function to call on state change
     */
    void attach(mbed::Callback<void()> func);
```

https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/features/netsocket/Socket.h#L157-L168

it would be useful if either the callback passed the state change as a parameter or a separate function was available to read the state change that generated the callback in the first place. 

This would allow the application to infer what commands the network stack is ready for next.

title: nsapi: Change initial state of sockets to allow events
body:
As pointed out by @kjbracey-arm, the previous behaviour was broken for sockets that started out listening.

Note, the registered callback is still disabled by a call to socket_attach. This will avoid being called after the socket is closed unless close is called from the attached callback, which is in irq context.

This effectively reverts https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/pull/3374, which contains a discussion on the expected behaviour.

This may also help standardize some of the change in behaviour that came out of https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/pull/3457.

cc @kjbracey-arm, @0xc0170

title: Building with RTOS via build.py does not build the appropriate code
body:
### Description
- Type: Bug
- Priority: Major

---------------------------------------------------------------
## Bug

**Target**
NUCLEO_L476RG

**Toolchain:**
GCC_ARM

**Expected behavior**
That source files such as "PlatformMutex.h" not compile in the stub implementations when the "--rtos" flag is provided to build.py, but would utilize the RTOS provided implementations.

**Actual behavior**
PlatforMutex.h (and others) use the stub implementation instead of the rtos implementation.  This is (in part) due to "MBED_CONF_RTOS_PRESENT" not being defined for the build of mbed.

**Steps to reproduce**
1. Checkout mbed-os repository
2. Edit "platform/PlatformMutex.h".  Insert an "#error" line in the stub build to demonstrate that the stub is being built.
3. Run "python tools/build.py -m NUCLEO_L476RG -t GCC_ARM --rtos -j1".  This will eventually fail with:

```
Compile [ 59.1%]: AnalogIn.cpp
[Error] PlatformMutex.h@26,0: #error 
In file included from /home/tim/idle/lib/mbed/BUILD/mbed/drivers/AnalogIn.h:25:0,
                 from /home/tim/idle/lib/mbed/drivers/AnalogIn.cpp:17:
/home/tim/idle/lib/mbed/BUILD/mbed/platform/PlatformMutex.h:26:2: error: #error 
```

title: Allow user overrides of LINKER_SCRIPT Make variable
body:
## Description
Allow `LINKER_SCRIPT` overrides via:

> `make LINKER_SCRIPT=something.ld -f Makefile`

The user can then set aside a block of flash memory for production config data by customizing the linker script like so: https://vilimpoc.org/blog/2016/12/25/flash-based-configuration-data-using-the-ld-linker/
